intro: Mentha anomala, commonly known as narrow-leaf mint, is a perennial herb native to Europe, Asia, and Africa. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender, lance-shaped leaves that have a strong mint scent. Its flowers are small, tubular, and typically pink or purple, appearing in clusters at the leaf axils. Mentha anomala is often used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb, though it is less commonly cultivated than other mint species.
